CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: Could the increased intelligence benefits from Muslim nations be compromised due to the strained relationships caused by Donald's dismissive and insulting rhetoric towards the Muslim community?
Does the fact that you're advocating for closer cooperation with Muslim nations and communities contradict your administration's past rhetoric and policies that have been perceived as Islamophobic?

If the US is seeking intelligence from Muslim-majority nations and relies on their cooperation to combat terrorism, would it not be contradictory to alienate and push away the American Muslim community?

If our allies, particularly those in the Middle East, are crucial in providing intelligence to combat terrorism, then why would we continue to alienate the American Muslim community through divisive rhetoric?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on the wealthy paying their fair share and closing corporate loopholes causes the increased tax burden to negatively affect the economic growth and overall job creation?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the "fair share" of the wealthy and closing corporate loopholes is the most effective way to address the issues of affordable childcare and debt-free college, rather than other potential solutions?

If Clinton's proposal for the wealthy to pay their fair share and close corporate loopholes is meant to improve the lives of Americans, why would that not extend to the idea that CEOs and executives, who are also part of the top 1%, should be held accountable for the struggles of their employees and workers?
If we're going to have a president who claims to improve people's lives, why should the wealthy be exempt from contributing to that improvement through increased taxes?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: What if the proposed policies that failed in the first place are the cause, and the resulting economic downturn is the effect, does that justify the claim that the current economic recovery is solely the result of Clinton's policies?
Do you, Mr. Clinton, have any scientific source to support the claim that the policies that failed the US in the past are the ones that will lead to a potentially much better economy?

If the economy was on the precipice of potentially having a much better economy after a devastating crisis, why would that not justify a more drastic approach to address climate change, rather than reverting to policies that failed in the first place?
If a policy that led to such devastating economic consequences under your administration can be considered successful now, does that imply that the end justifies the means?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: Does the invocation of Article 5 by NATO in response to 9/11 justify the continued involvement of NATO in military actions against countries like Iran, where the threat of nuclear proliferation was cited as a justification?

Does the Article 5 collective defense commitment of NATO, as invoked after 9/11, justify US-led military action against a nation like Iran, even when the latter is accused of developing nuclear capabilities?

If NATO invoked Article 5 after 9/11 to fight terrorism, can't the US and its allies invoke a similar collective defense against a nuclear threat from a country like Iran, which was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb?
If the 28 nations of NATO invoked Article 5 after 9/11 to fight terrorism, shouldn't they also invoke it now to support the United States in its conflict with Iran?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that the sanctions were imposed without firing a single shot imply that the diplomatic efforts, rather than military action, were indeed the most effective cause?
Do you consider the success of your sanctions and diplomatic efforts in Iran a stronger indicator of your leadership abilities than the current state of the country's nuclear program?

Does Clinton's ability to negotiate with Russia and China to impose sanctions on Iran demonstrate a capability to use diplomacy, but does her failure to support the Iran deal as President reflect a lack of good judgment?
If Clinton's diplomatic efforts were successful in halting Iran's nuclear program without firing a single shot, why does her approach not justify similar efforts in dealing with North Korea?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of the right temperament for a commander-in-chief causes them to make decisions that affect national security?
Do you believe a commander-in-chief's temperament can be judged solely based on a single public speech, rather than a comprehensive analysis of their leadership skills and policies?
If being taunted by foreign leaders is seen as a disqualification for the office of commander-in-chief, would being taunted by domestic leaders also disqualify a person from holding the same office?
If Clinton's temperament is indeed unsuitable for a commander-in-chief, then what makes him a suitable choice for the role?

CLINTON_231.input:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: What if the cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons by a leader like Clinton causes the threat of nuclear terrorism to escalate?

Do you have any evidence that President Clinton's statement about the threat of nuclear weapons being the number-one threat we face in the world is supported by actual data or expert analysis rather than his personal opinion?

If a cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons by a world leader is considered a top threat, how does this not equate to the threat posed by a cavalier attitude towards climate change or other pressing global issues?

If his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is deeply troubling, why does Clinton not take a more severe stance against countries like North Korea that are also recklessly handling nuclear material?

CLINTON_235.input:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: Does the influence of the problem on the public's perception of the issue cause a shift in the politician's stance on the matter?
Do you have a scientific source that supports your claim that the statement "It's a good one, though" effectively addresses the problem you are referring to?
Does Clinton's response imply that he sees the analogy between systemic racism and the struggles of marginalized groups as accurately describing a fundamental issue?
If he did such a great job making peace, why do we need sanctions to pressure North Korea into stopping its violent threats?

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: What if a president who lacks a clear plan to address a major security threat like ISIS ends up undermining the public's trust in their leadership and ability to make decisions that further peace and prosperity?
Does the President's claim of having a secret plan to defeat ISIS contradict his history of not disclosing a clear, detailed plan, undermining the trust of the international community?

If the Iranian deal that Clinton refers to as successful is considered a secret plan, wouldn't that undermine the transparency and accountability that she claims is necessary for the American people to trust her leadership?

If we should be able to count on our leaders to make decisions that further peace and prosperity, why should we not be able to count on him to reveal his plan to defeat ISIS, instead of keeping it a secret?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: What if the deployment of a half a billion more solar panels causes a surge in energy production but fails to address the underlying economic issues that led to the trouble in the first place?
Do you believe that the proposed economic solutions you've outlined will be sufficient to address the underlying issues that led to the economic troubles in the first place?

If deploying a half a billion more solar panels and building a new modern electric grid are considered crucial steps for a strong economy, would prioritizing these efforts domestically over addressing global issues also be seen as a necessary step?

If we can deploy a half a billion more solar panels and have enough clean energy to power every home, does that alone justify ignoring the underlying causes of the economic trouble that led to the eight years of stagnation?

CLINTON_37.input:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

cqs.cq: Does the increase in American exports during your tenure as secretary of state directly cause the decrease in the percentage of the population that voted against CAFTA?
Do you have any scientific evidence or data to support the claim that a 30 percent increase in American exports during your tenure as Secretary of State led to the creation of more new jobs?

If increasing exports to China by 50% during her time as secretary of state is seen as a significant accomplishment, why is the lack of enforcement of trade deals and accountability of those who break them not considered a significant challenge in the economy?

If increasing exports to China by 50 percent while being secretary of state was beneficial, why did you vote against CAFTA, a multinational trade deal that could potentially boost exports even further?

CLINTON_39.input:
CLINTON: "I've been a senator, Donald
...
You haven't done it.
 I have been a secretary of state
And I have done a lot"

cqs.cq: What if being a senator or secretary of state actually causes the public to view your ability to do a lot as more relevant than your actual accomplishments?
Do you have any evidence to support the claim that being a senator and being a secretary of state are comparable accomplishments?
Does the fact that you've held multiple high-level positions, like a senator and secretary of state, not give you a more substantial claim to leadership than someone who has not held such positions?
If you've been a secretary of state and claim to have done a lot, does that imply that you've done more than Donald Trump in his role as a senator?

CLINTON_55.input:
CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world
it's important to look at what we need to do to get the economy going again
new jobs with rising incomes, investments, not in more tax cuts that would add $5 trillion to the debt"

cqs.cq: Would tax cuts adding $5 trillion to the debt cause the economy to recover faster than the proposed investments in new jobs with rising incomes?
Do you have any evidence from the Clinton presidency or any other administration that consistently cutting taxes led to the desired economic growth and not increasing the national debt?

If the economic growth and job creation that Clinton emphasizes are prioritized over reducing the national debt, does that resemble the way her policies would address the country's long-term fiscal health?

If Clinton emphasizes the importance of economic growth and reducing the national debt, then why does her proposed economic plan not address the substantial impact of her husband's tax cuts on the national debt?

CLINTON_57.input:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: What if the plan that you claim would create 10 million jobs and your opponent's plan would lose us 3.5 million jobs is actually a cause that would lead to a recession?

Do you have any empirical evidence from your book "Stronger Together" that supports your claim that your economic plan would create 10 million jobs and your opponent's plan would result in a recession?
If a politician's written book is considered a viable plan, would a presidential candidate's published book be considered a viable policy?
If CLINTON's plan would lose us 3.5 million jobs and explode the debt, then how can he claim that his plan is more beneficial for the economy than the one proposed by you?

CLINTON_66.input:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: What if the fact that what you have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy ends up causing a significant shift in public opinion and affect the political landscape?
Do you have any evidence that the wealthy and corporations have historically paid their fair share to support the country, given the historical context of tax policies under previous administrations?
If the wealthy and corporations have made all the gains in the economy, why should they not be held accountable for paying their fair share to support the country?
If CLINTON's plan would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses, then why would the wealthy and corporations not already be paying their fair share to support this country?

CLINTON_6_1.input:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: If the 5 percent of the world's population that the US represents has to trade with the other 95 percent, would it not be more beneficial to prioritize fair trade deals over trickle-down economics?
Can you provide evidence that the 95% of the world's population outside of the US has a better understanding of how to grow the economy than the US has had under previous Republican administrations?

If the United States accounts for only 5% of the world's population and is expected to trade with the other 95%, wouldn't it be beneficial to prioritize fair trade deals and economic growth over solely rewarding financial transactions?
If Clinton is advocating for a tax system that rewards work, does this imply that she views wealth acquired through inheritance or privilege as being less valuable than that earned through hard work?

CLINTON_6_2.input:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on helping wealthy individuals by Clinton is actually causing a widening economic gap, which in turn affects the middle class's ability to invest in their education and skills?
Does your father's experience as a small-businessman and your personal experience align with your claim that investing in the middle class is the key to a better economy?
Does his claim that helping the middle class is key to a better economy align with the fact that he started his business with borrowed money from his father, rather than through his own hard work?

If his father's small business, which required manual labor and skill, is more representative of the economy he wants to see, why is it that he now relies on his own wealth and privilege, rather than the struggles of his father, to guide his vision?

CLINTON_85.input:
CLINTON: "let 's start the clock again , Lester
We 've looked at your tax proposals
I do n't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you 're referring to that would cause the repatriation , bringing back of money that 's stranded overseas
I happen to support that"

cqs.cq: What if the repatriation of money that's stranded overseas is caused by the corporate tax rate changes, then why does the President's support for the changes not influence the decisions of multinational corporations to repatriate the funds?
Can you provide any scientific evidence that supports the claim that corporate tax rate changes would directly lead to the repatriation of money that's stranded overseas?

If the US government can repatriate corporate funds that have been "stranded overseas" for decades, would that imply that the concept of "stranded" assets should also apply to the historical wealth of minority communities that have been "stranded" for generations?
If President Clinton claims we should start the clock again, does he imply that he sees the current tax proposals as ineffective?

CLINTON_87.input:
CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit
when I look at what you have proposed , you have what is called now the Trump loophole
it would so advantage you and the business you do"

cqs.cq: What if the influence of the Trump loophole causes a shift in CLINTON's political stance to favor the business interests over the public good?

Do you have any expert opinion or scientific evidence to support the claim that your proposed policy would "actually work to our benefit" when considering the potential drawbacks and implications of the so-called "Trump loophole"?
If a politician's personal financial interests are prioritized over the public good, why does that not resemble a conflict of interest?
If CLINTON says the Trump loophole would advantage him, does that imply that he believes the current system is inherently biased in his favor?

CLINTON_92.input:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance their—their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: Does the trickle-down approach, which has historically been associated with tax cuts for the wealthy, actually lead to inclusive economic growth that benefits the middle class?
Does the idea that trickle-down economics is a failed policy, as you mentioned, align with the empirical evidence on the economic growth and recovery in the US after the 2008 financial crisis?

If trickle-down economics, which have been shown to not work, and top-down policies, which are also ineffective, why would the approach of the wealthy dictating economic policy not be seen as a viable solution?
If trickle-down economics didn't work during the economic crisis in 2008 and 2009, why would its implementation now be expected to magically boost the economy?

CL_57.input:
CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is fool’s gold, not real wealth at all."

cqs.cq: What if the suppression of moral hazard causes the lenders to lose the ability to accurately assess the risk of lending, thereby affecting their financial decisions?
Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that ignoring moral hazard in lending and borrowing leads to the creation of "fool's gold" rather than real wealth?
If the process of lending and borrowing inherently involves moral hazard, does that not imply that the benefits of the transaction are also subject to moral hazard, rather than being genuine wealth?
If you claim that ignoring moral hazard can lead to generating wealth that's not real, doesn't that imply that all your financial gains are also potentially illusory?

Doctor-Mom_205.input:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: What if the decision to ban peanut products on airlines causes a significant increase in the cost of flights, potentially making air travel unaffordable for many people who may not have access to safe food alternatives?

Do you have any peer-reviewed studies or data from your "3000 member" online support forums that scientifically validate the claim that peanut products pose a life-threatening risk to individuals merely through contact or inhalation, without any documented cases of such incidents occurring in real-world scenarios?
If airline peanuts are a potential life-threatening hazard, why would the airline industry not consider removing all food options altogether, rather than selectively banning peanuts?

If a doctor who has dedicated a website to support food allergy sufferers and claims to have 3000 members, why should their personal opinions on airline food choices be given more weight than the concerns of the airline industry itself?

Elmattador__92.input:
Elmattador: "you must have missed the GOP debates"
 < this message is answering to > 
Bigtwinkie: "This debate has honestly been making me uncomfortable
its been way too hostile
Its like listening to mom and dad fight in the kitchen while your hide under the covers in your room
 all they succeed at is making the entire panel seem unlikable
the democratic nominee will be bleeding votes no matter who wins"

cqs.cq: What if the divisive nature of the debates causes the general public to become disillusioned with the entire political process?

Do you have a scientific source that supports your claim that the dynamic between the GOP debates is comparable to a family argument in a way that it would significantly impact voters' perception of the democratic nominee?
Does the tone of the GOP debates reflect the same level of civility and respect that one might expect from a family kitchen argument?
If the debate is indeed making the entire panel seem unlikable, does that not reflect poorly on the tone of the party that's hosting it?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.input:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: What if the severity of your child's peanut allergy causes his future employer to deny him the accommodations he needs to safely perform his job duties, potentially affecting his career prospects?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the notion that children with severe food allergies should be prioritized over other individuals in terms of airline travel accommodations?

If individuals with life-threatening peanut allergies are considered to have a disability that affects their ability to participate in certain activities, should individuals with life-threatening allergies to other substances, such as certain medications, be considered similarly disabled?
If a child's life is worth risking due to the unpredictability of peanut allergy, should the same consideration not be applied to the millions of people who fly daily with the same allergy risk?

Frequent-Flyer_157.input:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: If requiring airlines to set aside peanut-free seating blocks would cause allergy sufferers to feel more comfortable, would this ultimately affect their decision to fly with peanuts, or would they still choose to avoid flying altogether?

Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that requiring carriers to reserve seating blocks for peanut-allergic passengers and asking others to forgo eating peanuts is more effective than simply allowing passengers to carry their "rescue" medication and take necessary precautions?

If requiring airlines to reserve seating blocks for peanut-allergic passengers is deemed a necessary accommodation, why not also require airlines to provide a designated "asthma-friendly" zone for passengers with respiratory issues?

If frequent-flyers like the one in the example can afford to consider alternate travel methods or take precautions to minimize their allergy risk, why should they expect others to sacrifice their freedom to eat peanuts to accommodate their needs?

Glblwrmingisfak__552.input:
Glblwrmingisfak: "What argument?
Nobody proposes common sense gun solutions
The DOJ over a decade ago already determined that an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US
It is not a solution for any of our problems
Bernie should know
he clearly isn't stupid"

cqs.cq: If we know that a ban on assault weapons has been deemed ineffective by the DOJ, then what argument can be made for Bernie's stance on advocating for such a policy?
Do you have any evidence that supports the claim that Bernie Sanders is not stupid, especially in the context of gun control policies?

If the DOJ has already determined that an assault weapons ban won't significantly impact homicide rates in the US, does that not suggest that proponents of such a ban are either misinformed or misleading?
If the DOJ already determined that an assault weapons ban won't address homicide rates, then how can Bernie's proposal be considered a viable solution?

HOLT_126.input:
HOLT: "Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York
it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men"

cqs.cq: Does the ruling that Stop-and-frisk was unconstitutional in New York largely single out black and Hispanic young men cause an increase in crime rates among those demographics?
Do you have any evidence from the court ruling that the Stop-and-frisk policy was specifically targeting black and Hispanic young men, rather than a broader demographic?

Does the court's decision to rule "Stop-and-frisk" unconstitutional not also imply that the practice of singling out black and Hispanic young men for police stops is inherently discriminatory and unjust?
If the Supreme Court deemed "Stop-and-frisk" unconstitutional, does that justify the claim that its implementation was inherently biased and discriminatory?

HOLT_239.input:
HOLT: "Which leads to my next question
we enter our last segment here on the , still on the subject of securing America
On nuclear weapons , President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation 's longstanding policy on first use
Do you support the current policy ?
Mr. Trump , you have two minutes on that"

cqs.cq: Does the policy of first-use nuclear weapons lead to a more stable and secure America?
Do you believe that the current nuclear first-use policy aligns with your stated views on national security?

If the US policy on first use of nuclear weapons is based on the assumption that it would deter other nations from using their own nuclear arms, wouldn't that logic also apply to the deterrence of other nations from engaging in other types of warfare?
If President Obama considered changing the nation's longstanding policy on first use, does that imply that the current policy is no longer effective in securing America?

HOLT_94.input:
HOLT: "we 're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay , yet you have not released your tax returns
the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money to—who he owes it to and any business conflicts
Do n't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest"

cqs.cq: Would the lack of transparency about potential conflicts of interest and financial obligations not undermine the democratic process and potentially harm American citizens?

Do you have any evidence that the public release of tax returns by presidential nominees is a universally established precedent that has been consistently upheld across all U.S. presidential candidates?
If nominees release their tax returns to reveal potential conflicts of interest, why should Americans not be entitled to know if a sitting president has any similar conflicts?
If nominees have released their returns for decades to ensure transparency, why should the president not be held to the same standard, considering the burden Americans have to pay?

Helen__66.input:
Helen: "they’re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes I’d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
it’s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: Does the presence of families with high levels of aggression and violence actually cause a decrease in the effectiveness of interventions aimed at helping other families in need?

Do you think that your assertion about certain families needing intervention is consistent with your earlier statement that families with high levels of aggression and violence should be allowed to impose their own levels without external intervention?

If Helen deems it right to intervene in families with high levels of aggression and violence, wouldn't it also be right to intervene in families who are perpetuating systemic violence and oppression, such as those who have historically and systematically terrorized communities?

If Helen believes intervention is necessary for some families with high levels of aggression and violence, then shouldn't she also advocate for intervention in cases where communities are being terrorised by those same families?

17th_knight__247.input:
17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"
 < this message is answering to > 
reaper527: "now you have a field of democrat presidential candidates supporting it
republicans used to get mocked and laughed at when they said that illegal immigrants would be getting obamacare coverage"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that the candidates are supporting illegal immigrants getting coverage imply that they will cause a shift in the party's stance on immigration, potentially affecting their future policies?
Do you have any evidence from a reputable source to support the claim that a significant number of Democrats support universal healthcare coverage for undocumented immigrants?
If the government provides healthcare to undocumented immigrants, wouldn't that imply that undocumented immigrants are a part of this society?
If they're advocating for healthcare coverage for undocumented immigrants, do they also believe that xenophobia should be ignored when it's expressed by others?

AFCHF_154.input:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: If DOT sets a maximum tarmac delay trigger that applies to all airlines and all classes of aircraft, would this policy lead to a reduction in flight delays and subsequent stress on passengers?

Do you have a military protocol or a scientific study that supports the claim that deplaning without CBP screening is a viable option, especially when compared to standard airport security procedures?
If airlines can legally commit to deplaning passengers during gate holds, why can't they also legally commit to deplaning passengers during tarmac delays?

If airlines can afford to compensate passengers for delays caused by tarmac holds, why should passengers be forced to remain in the immediate area without access to amenities or compensation during CBP screening delays?

AK-traveler_186.input:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: Would allowing airlines to charge for items necessary due to factors outside passengers' control, such as seat size and configuration, ultimately cause a decline in airline safety and passenger health?
Do you believe that airline companies are prioritizing profits over passenger health and well-being by charging for seat space and imposing pet fees without providing adequate alternatives?
If airlines can charge exorbitant fees for carrying pets, why can't they be held accountable for providing adequate space for passengers to perform exercises to prevent deep vein thrombosis?

If passengers are required to pay for airline services like pet carry-on fees, then why should they be exempt from paying for necessary items like food and water that are also crucial to their survival?

AllergyDad_200.input:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: Would the increased risk of anaphylaxis on airplanes cause a ban on peanut and tree nut products to be implemented by the DOT?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that a blanket ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights would completely eliminate the risk of anaphylaxis for all passengers with allergies?
If a peanut can be fatal to a child, why should tree nuts, which pose the same risks, be allowed on flights without similar precautions?
If a child's life is worth banning peanuts and tree nuts from airplanes, then why not also ban peanuts and tree nuts from schools and other public places where they could pose a threat to children?

AngelComa__638.input:
AngelComa: "Funny, I thought he did good
They get timed responses
his plan is all there
He can't talk about everything in the plan
Must be how used you are to politicians saying things and not having a plan"
 < this message is answering to > 
Punchee: "That was a weird moment in American debate history. "Yo check my website. Shit's on there.""

cqs.cq: Does the fact that a politician made a claim about having a plan, but then unable to discuss it, affect how voters perceive the politician's credibility?
Do you have a scientific source or personal experience that validates your claim about the politician's plan being "all there" when you couldn't discuss everything in it?
If a politician can't articulate their plan, is it truly a difference from when a politician says something but has no plan?
If his plan is indeed all there, then why is he unable to discuss it publicly?

Antanagoge_104.input:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: If airlines are unable to provide accurate and complete information, can this cause a significant increase in anxiety and stress among passengers?

Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that the airline industry is capable of effectively self-regulating its customer service quality to a level that outweighs the risks associated with its variability?
If airline customer service can be so inaccurate that it poses a significant risk of death and humiliation, why can't the airline industry be held accountable for its own self-regulation?

If the airline industry can't be left to self-monitor this, then why would we trust them to provide accurate information about peanuts on flights, which could be a matter of life and death for some passengers?

Antanagoge_111.input:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: What if the publication of studies by medical associations and journals, which could potentially sway the opinions of the opponents, is not enough to cause a shift in their prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the notion that individuals who demand funerals before entertaining a compromise position are representative of the tyranny of the majority?

If the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, can publish studies on allergy and asthma, why do they not publish studies on the impact of systemic racism and microaggressions on public health?

If the opponents of accommodations already have access to full text studies yet still harbor a prejudgment against researchers, does that indicate a predisposition to ignore evidence-based discussions?

Antanagoge_227.input:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: What if the presence of peanut allergens in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin causes anaphylactic shock in passengers with severe peanut allergies?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the air onboard an airliner is "much cleaner" than people think, despite the study you mentioned suggesting peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners?

If the peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin, wouldn't the airline industry's efforts to minimize exposure be analogous to how hospitals handle the presence of airborne pathogens in patient rooms?

If peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin, then why does the fact that a confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported, albeit in 1998, not justify a blanket ban on serving peanuts on flights?

Antanagoge_239.input:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: If the peanut allergy hysteria is indeed ridiculous, then why should the potential risks of peanuts on airplanes be considered a public health menace?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that peanuts are a public health menace comparable to tobacco smoking?
If peanuts are considered a nutritious and universally enjoyed food, how can they be compared to tobacco, which is widely acknowledged as a public health menace?
If peanuts are indeed so beneficial and nearly universally enjoyed, then why should they be considered a public health menace and subject to such restrictive measures?

Bill_106.input:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: If airlines are allowed to charge customers such disparate prices for the same ticket, wouldn't this cause widespread consumer distrust and mistrust?
Do you have any evidence that the airline industry's practice of charging extra fees, such as taxes, isn't a form of bait and switch, which is indeed considered deceptive and potentially illegal?
If airlines can be held accountable for "Bait and Switch" tactics, why can't they also be held accountable for "Bait and Add" tactics?
If airlines are guilty of Bait and Switch tactics, shouldn't the airline industry be subject to stricter regulations to prevent deceptive pricing practices?

CF_29.input:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldn’t encourage it for ourselves either
That’s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, there’s a danger I think when you kind of say, “The poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.”
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isn’t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they haven’t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: Does the notion that the wealthy have a responsibility to use their influence to drive social progress outweigh the potential risks associated with their investments?
Do you have any evidence to support the claim that the primary issue with banks is solely providing consumer credit rather than taking more risk and giving more money out?
Wouldn't the wealthy's historical contributions to social progress also imply a responsibility to prioritize lending over consumption?

If the banks are indeed capable of making a significant positive impact through their investments, why do they primarily focus on consumer credit rather than more substantial and potentially beneficial risk-taking initiatives?

CF_46.input:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries – and now the sufferers – of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
“Well, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?”
And you do actually want to say, “Money doesn’t grow on trees.”"

cqs.cq: Do you think the beneficiaries of the sub-prime mortgage policies are actually the ones who should bear the burden of the economic consequences, rather than the general public?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that economic frustration and consumer credit-based policies are more significant drivers of societal attitudes than the supposed "real state of the economy"?

Does the notion that systemic issues can be addressed through consumer credit rather than fundamental policy changes resemble the idea that medical issues can be solved through vitamins rather than healthcare reform?
If your primary concern is the real state of the economy, why do you suggest that people assume everything can carry on without necessary adjustments?

CLINTON_103.input:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: What if the secrecy surrounding Clinton's tax returns causes the public to question his honesty about his wealth and charitable donations?

Does the fact that President Clinton has released his tax returns for a limited period under state audit requirements provide a reasonable explanation for why his tax returns are not publicly available for the entire 40 years he claimed?
If the public can access nearly 40 years of tax returns from other presidential candidates, why can't the public access the entirety of Donald Trump's tax returns?
If he has made a point about the importance of transparency in tax returns, then why hasn't he led by example by releasing his own tax returns?

CLINTON_123_1.input:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: If race continues to determine where people live, what effect does this have on the quality of education in their public schools?

Do you have any concrete, data-driven evidence to support the claim that racial disparities in the criminal justice system are more pronounced in the United States than in other countries with similar racial demographics?

If the racial disparities in treatment by law enforcement and access to education are acknowledged as systemic issues, why should we not consider the racial disparities in wealth, health, and economic opportunities as equally significant challenges?
If restoring trust between communities and the police is essential, does that imply that the current lack of trust is more damaging than the racial disparities Clinton mentioned?

CLINTON_123_2.input:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of effective community engagement and police reform causes the gun epidemic to continue being the leading cause of death of young African-American men?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that gun violence is the leading cause of death of young African-American men, more than the next nine causes put together?

If restoring trust between law enforcement and communities requires mutual respect, why does it not also require acknowledging and addressing the historical trauma and systemic injustices faced by African-American communities?

If Clinton's platform aims to address the gun epidemic, why doesn't it also explicitly address the root causes of the epidemic, such as the fact that guns are often in the hands of people who should not have them?

CLINTON_130_1.input:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe
There are the right ways of doing it
then there are ways that are ineffective
Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional
in part, because it was ineffective
It did not do what it needed to do
I believe in community policing
in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991
Property crime is down 40 percent
We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: If Clinton's criticism of Trump's portrayal of black communities is rooted in the belief that his policies are ineffective, then why does she not acknowledge that her own approach to community policing, which included the use of stop-and-frisk, also had some ineffective aspects?
Do you have any evidence to support the claim that community policing, as you've described it, has been effective in reducing crime rates without the issues associated with stop-and-frisk?
If Clinton views stop-and-frisk as ineffective and unconstitutional, would she not also see community policing as ineffective if it disproportionately targets African-American and Latino communities?
If Clinton's alternative policing methods have been effective in reducing crime, then why did she not implement such measures when she was president?

CLINTON_130_2.input:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system
We cannot just say law and order
we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system
deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little
We need to have more second chance programs
I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system
I want to see them ended in the state system
You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans
here are some positive ways we can work on this
I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us
Right now—and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby—right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets
this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby
In a lot of places, our police are outgunned
We need comprehensive background checks
we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm
we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country
If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun
there are things we can do
we ought to do it in a bipartisan way"

cqs.cq: What if the systemic racism in our criminal justice system causes the disproportionate incarceration of young African-American men to lead to a breakdown in trust between law enforcement and minority communities?

Do you have a scientific study or a credible source that supports the claim that African-American men are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated than white men, beyond just anecdotal evidence?

If the likelihood of arrest, conviction, and incarceration for African-American men is higher than for white men for similar actions, does this not suggest a systemic issue with the justice system that extends beyond individual cases?

If the criminal justice system disproportionately targets young African-American men, shouldn't the systemic racism in our justice system be addressed before implementing more stringent gun safety measures?

CLINTON_147.input:
CLINTON: "New York has done an excellent job
I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs
it has worked
other communities need to come together to do what will work
one murder is too many
it is important that we learn about what has been effective
not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want
Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe
no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods
we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of effective collaboration with the communities, faith communities, business communities, and the police causes the ineffective response to the problem of youth violence in neighborhoods?

Do you believe that Mayor Clinton's approach, which emphasizes community collaboration and evidence-based solutions, is more effective than solely relying on law enforcement in addressing community safety issues?

If two mayors and two police chiefs in New York were able to achieve significant progress in reducing crime, would other cities not have a similar opportunity to work collaboratively with various community groups to address the issue?
If New York has done an excellent job in reducing killings, then shouldn't we also be doing an excellent job in addressing the root causes of these killings?

CLINTON_17.input:
CLINTON: "let 's stop for a second and remember where we were eight years ago
We had the worst financial crisis , the Great Recession
the worst since the 1930s
 slashed taxes on the wealthy
failed to invest in the middle class
took their eyes off of Wall Street
created a perfect storm
was in large part because of tax policies
Donald was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis
...
 it did collapse"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that the wealthy received tax cuts contribute to the economic instability that led to the Great Recession?
Do you have a scientific source that confirms that the policies you're attributing to Donald Trump were indeed the primary cause of the 2008 financial crisis?
If the wealthy were responsible for the devastating economic collapse, why should their policies be the ones to guide the nation's recovery?
If he was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis, does that imply that he also contributed to the economic collapse that followed?

CLINTON_176_1.input:
CLINTON: "cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president
clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries
There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money
increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states
The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia
There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country
I am deeply concerned about this
Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin
Putin is playing a really tough, long game here
one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee"

cqs.cq: Will the Russian government's willingness to let loose cyber attackers compromise the integrity of US government and personal files, thereby undermining the country's cyber security?
Does the President's assessment of Putin's actions as a "tough, long game" imply a tacit endorsement of Russia's cyber warfare tactics?

If the President is deeply concerned about Russia's cyber attacks, would that not mean the President should also be concerned about the potential threat of domestic cyber attacks by independent hacking groups?

If cyber security is one of the biggest challenges facing the next president, does that imply that President Clinton's administration was unprepared to handle the threats from Russia and other adversaries?

CLINTON_176_2.input:
CLINTON: "we recently have learned that, you know, that this is one of their preferred methods of trying to wreak havoc and collect information
We need to make it very clear—whether it's Russia, China, Iran or anybody else—the United States has much greater capacity
we are not going to sit idly by and permit state actors to go after our information, our private-sector information or our public-sector information
 we're going to have to make it clear that we don't want to use the kinds of tools that we have
We don't want to engage in a different kind of warfare
we will defend the citizens of this country

cqs.cq: Do you think the fact that you're basing your voting decision on a politician's speaking style rather than policy issues will cause you to make uninformed choices?
Do you consider your voting preference based on a politician's charisma over a comprehensive analysis of their policy positions?

If voters are expected to base their political opinions on a candidate's presentation skills rather than policy issues, does that imply that a politician's charisma and stage presence are more important than their actual policy stances?
If you claim you're voting based on who's more articulate, does that imply you value style over substance in politics?

Vec_164.input:
Vec: "The rules definitely need to be spelled out as specifically as possible
and should apply to all airlines
I don't trust the airlines to develop and enforce their own policy.
Previous experience with getting bumped off a flight (I was using miles) and the airline refused to put me on another carrier's flight
instead I had a flight that was six hours later with absolutely no compensation.
Basically the customer servie rep's attitude was "It's not my problem and you're using miles so we owe you nothing.""

cqs.cq: Would the lack of clear and specific rules and regulations for airlines lead to inconsistent and unfair treatment of passengers like you, causing a cause of frustration and mistrust?
Do you have any personal experience or scientific evidence that suggests airlines consistently enforce their own policies, especially when passengers are bumped from flights?
If airlines can be trusted to develop and enforce their own policies, why would that not justify trusting them to handle customer service disputes without government intervention?
If airlines are expected to develop and enforce their own policies, then why should passengers be forced to rely on airlines to spell out their rules specifically?

Velshtein__565.input:

 he's a shitty candidate who can't substantiate any of the bullshit he spouts
The fact that all you morons lap it up only compounds on it"
 < this message is answering to > 
Kagawaful: "So many people are so desperate for bernie to fail
Anyone who thinks Hilary is a better candidate is an idiot
We get it, you dont like him
he is popular on reddit"

cqs.cq: If people are so desperate for Bernie to fail, do they think their desperation is a cause of his perceived popularity on Reddit?
Do you have any credible evidence to support the claim that being a candidate's popularity on Reddit is a valid indicator of their suitability for office?

If people who criticize a candidate for lacking substance and being popular on Reddit are considered rational, why would those who enthusiastically support a candidate who lacks substance and is popular on Reddit be considered anything other than equally misguided?
If you claim that Bernie is a bad candidate, then do you also believe that his popularity on Reddit makes him a worse candidate?

Zewstain__641.input:
Zewstain: "It seemed like that was most of her argument. Being a woman
How will you differ from Obama? Hillary: As a woman it's clear. Cooper: Any policy differences? Hillary: Hello, I'm a woman"

cqs.cq: How does Hillary's argument that being a woman is a significant factor in her policy differences with Obama differ from Cooper's argument that being a woman is simply a greeting?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that being a woman is a sufficient basis for Hillary Clinton to have unique policy perspectives or priorities compared to other politicians?
If being a woman is the only argument Hillary has, would that imply she has no other qualifications or qualifications aside from her gender?
If Hillary's primary claim is being a woman, how does that distinguish her from other women who have held the same office, like Obama?

aimwill_178.input:
aimwill: "Perhaps i am missing something here
If airlines are selling the seats for full price and people don't show up for the flight, doesn't the airline still pocket that money?
And with the hubbub about the extra weight of luggage, wouldn't having a few empty seats DECREASE the cost of the flight by increasing fuel efficiency?
Like I said, I may be missing a key detail, but it really does seem like the airlines are gambling that people won't show up and they can get paid twice for the same seat.
If the airlines are refunding people based on them missing flights, perhaps stopping THAT practice and disallowing overbooking would solve the problem??
If someone is really worried about missing their flight and being compensated, they can buy trip insurance.
The rest of us won't have to worry about getting bumped.
I think so :)"

cqs.cq: Would the airline's practice of refunding people based on them missing flights not incentivize airlines to overbook flights even more, thus creating a vicious cycle?
Do you think airlines could indeed be profiting from the practice of overbooking and refunding passengers, rather than simply trying to minimize the financial losses from no-shows?
Would airlines not be profiting twice from the same seat if they continue to sell it and refund passengers who don't show up, rather than just selling it once?
If the airline is refunding passengers based on them missing flights, wouldn't that practice create a perverse incentive for people to miss flights, thus making the problem worse?

ambersky_145.input:
ambersky: "I agree with chartley81.
My child has a right to live.
What about the fact that other things have been banned on airlines
I think you can survive not eating peanuts for a few hours,
but my son may not survive the flight if you decide to touch the armrest with a peanut oil covered hand and then he touches it.
yes there are always risks
but banning it lessens that risk to an extent."

cqs.cq: Do you think the risk of your child's health being affected by peanut oil on an armrest outweighs the inconvenience of not eating peanuts on an airline?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the risk of a child's health being compromised by touching an armrest with peanut oil is significantly higher than the risk of an allergic reaction from peanuts?
