If a child's health can be jeopardized by exposure to a peanut oil contaminated armrest, why would the health of a passenger with a peanut allergy be less of a concern than the inconvenience of not serving peanuts on an airline?

If banning peanuts on airlines is a necessary measure to minimize risk, then why is not implementing a similar measure to ban violent threats in North Korea not also necessary to minimize the risk of harm to children?

annoyed_177.input:
annoyed: "Is there any formula that says how much airlines can overbook?
Should it be proportional to number of seats available?
Also, what about bumping according to when the ticket was purchased?
I plan well ahead of time and resent being bumped since I may have paid less.
Zero fare passengers should most certainly be compensated in some way."
 < this message is answering to > 
citizen-s: "I strongly support cash compensation for bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets,
But to assure adequate compensation and prevent airlines gaming such a requirement,
compensation should be at the average (cash) ticket price for that service class on that flight.
DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket would encourage airlines to bump those with zeroprice tickets first,
since that cost would be lowest.
As long as they continue to offer tickets for miles, airlines should not be encouraged to treat passengers using those tickets as secondclass when it comes to bumping.
The growing scarcity of actual seats for miles
something that cries out for regulatory intervention
is bad enough."

cqs.cq: Does the DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket price encourage airlines to unfairly prioritize bumping passengers with zero-price tickets over those who paid a higher fare?

Do you think the DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket would incentivize airlines to prioritize bumping passengers with zero-price tickets over those with average-priced tickets, thereby undermining the principle of fair compensation?
Should airlines be incentivized to prioritize bumping passengers with higher-priced tickets over those with zero-fare tickets, when the former often represent the airline's most profitable customers?

If airlines are required to compensate passengers with zero-fare tickets fairly, why should the average ticket price for that service class be used instead of the actual ticket price, which could be higher?

atraveller_82_1.input:
atraveller: "Although we always travel with epipens in case our fiveryearold peanut & tree nut allergic child needs them,
I think having some on board is a good idea,
as long as crew are trained in the proper usage.
Moreover, I think the crew need training on how to respectfully treat people with allergies or disabilities.
Since our son was diagnosed with the allergy one year ago, we have travelled several times on multiple carriers and have found the foreign carriers to be far less worrisome for those with nut allergies.
In fact, none of the foreign carriers we used during that time even served nuts in economy."

cqs.cq: Do you think the training of crew in the proper usage of epipens would cause a significant reduction in the anxiety experienced by families with peanut allergies when travelling on foreign carriers?

Do you have any empirical evidence or expert opinions that support the claim that all foreign carriers you've travelled with have been more accommodating to passengers with nut allergies than domestic carriers?

If airlines in countries with strict nut allergy protocols can accommodate travelers with allergies, why can't American carriers implement similar measures to provide a safer experience for passengers with allergies or disabilities?
If foreign carriers have been able to successfully accommodate nut allergies, then why can't domestic carriers also provide adequate support and training for passengers with severe allergies?

atraveller_82_2.input:
atraveller: "Our only trouble came with Delta.
On flights to and from Atlanta to El Salvador, I requested a nutfree buffer zone as listed as an option on the Delta website.
This request was not observed on either flight,
and I when mentioned it to the cabin crew on one segment, they began taking back the nuts from the passengers around us, pointing out that they couldn't have it because "that little boy is allergic."
This made us very uncomfortable, but at least the other passengers were polite about it.
I find it amazing that people get so incensed about "their rights" to have nuts being infringed upon.
I have a feeling that these are the same people who would be the first to complain when a plane has to make an emergency landing when a nutallergic passenger goes into anaphylaxis."

cqs.cq: Does the prioritization of accommodating a single nut-allergic passenger cause a flight crew to disregard the requests of other passengers who may also have legitimate dietary concerns?
Do you believe that the rights of passengers with nut allergies should be prioritized over the convenience of other passengers?
If people are so concerned about their rights to have nuts on a flight, why do they not show similar concern when a plane makes an emergency landing due to a nut-allergic passenger's health issue?

If Delta is so concerned about accommodating passengers with nut allergies, shouldn't they also prioritize the comfort and safety of passengers who may have other severe allergies, like the anaphylaxis risk you mentioned?

cd38_220_1.input:
cd38: "As someone who carries an epipen for beestings,
I understand that allergies can be serious and life threatening.
Banning airlines from serving peanuts inflight seems reasonable;
several posts mention the risk inherent in many people opening bags of peanuts at one time
(which can easily happen when snacks are served)
throwing a large amount of dust in the air,
which could be enough to trigger an allergy in severely allergic people.
However, banning people from carrying on their own snacks does seem to violate their rights,
to eliminate what seems like an extremely small risk to allergysufferers.
Nuts are a healthy, portable form of protein,
and cannot be replaced by pretzels.
No, being hungry or not eating protein won't kill someone;
but, I'm a vegetarian,
and  I fly constantly, often on longhaul international flights, but mainly between the east and west coasts,"

cqs.cq: Would banning peanuts from being served on flights cause a significant increase in the number of people carrying their own allergenic foods, thereby potentially violating the rights of those who rely on those foods for nutrition?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the risks associated with peanuts on flights are significant enough to justify banning passengers from carrying their own snacks?

If banning airlines from serving peanuts on flights is justified due to the risk of triggering severe allergic reactions, should airlines also consider banning passengers from carrying their own snacks to minimize the risk of cross-contamination?

If banning peanuts on flights is necessary to prevent severe reactions, then shouldn't we also consider banning other common allergenic foods like shellfish, or even peanuts' less severe cousin, tree nuts?

cd38_220_2.input:
cd38: "The return flight is 6 ½ hours (plus commute time to the airport);
when time allows, I make something to bring on the flight,
but if my mother is having a bad day, that's not always possible.
On a recent trip, I didn't have time to eat anything at all the day I flew home; got stuck in traffic and barely made my flight (I was the last one on) so didn't have time to eat or buy anything at the airport; and as we started to taxi, the flight crew announced that we had a nut allergy on board, and that they (JB) would not be serving cashews and requested that we not eat any nuts we may have brought on board.
6 ½ hours feels pretty long at that point!
No, it didn't kill me,
but it does seem that if JB hadn't served cashews, the risks involved in one or two people eating nuts they may have brought with them would have been extremely, extremely small....
and, NOTHING in life is riskfree.
I understand that people want to minimize the risks for their loved ones,
but you cannot eliminate the risk completely, regardless of what legislation you put in place.
If I ate peanuts at the airport, didn't wash my hands, and then opened the rest room door on the plane immediately before a peanut allergy sufferer, that person could suffer a reaction.
I can support airlines not serving peanuts/peanut products,
thereby eliminating the most likely possible cause of a peanutrelated incident on a flight;
but not restrictions on what people may choose to eat."

cqs.cq: Would the absence of peanuts on flights significantly reduce the risk of peanut-related incidents, thereby causing a decrease in the number of passengers affected by peanut allergies?

Do you think it is a more effective risk management strategy for airlines to completely ban peanuts and peanut products on flights, rather than allowing passengers to bring and consume their own, potentially triggering a reaction in fellow passengers with allergies?
If serving cashews on a flight poses a risk to passengers with nut allergies, why does serving peanuts pose a risk to passengers with peanut allergies?

If airlines can justify restricting the serving of peanuts to minimize the risk of a peanut-related incident, then should they not also consider restricting passengers from bringing peanuts on board to minimize the risk of a peanut-related incident?

citizen-s_134.input:
citizen-s: "DOT's objective in setting this rule should be to ELIMINATE all bumping, not merely achieve some (unspecified) reduction.
Regardless of how many caveats an airline might state in its contract terms, passengers neither want nor deserve a ticket for an oversold seat.
Bumping is a purely economic device that treats passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, like so many other aspects of airline behavior.
From that objective, it follows that there should be NO cap on compensation
and that the financial penalty to the airline should be strong enough to prevent bumping, not just keep it at some arbitrarily "acceptable" level.
The 100% of the total ticket price for expected arrival within 2 hours later is reasonable.
Compensation for a longer delay should be the GREATER of 200% of the total ticket cost or the passenger's demonstrable outofpocket costs resulting from the delay
(a) including any higher priced air ticket from the same or another carrier at the same class, and lodging, meals and incidentals at average prevailing prices in that metro area,
and (b) with the obligation on the passenger to minimize those costs by arranging, with good faith help from the airline, an alternate flight or other means to get him or her to the destination as soon as reasonably practical."

cqs.cq: What if the primary goal of eliminating all bumping is not achieved due to a cap on compensation that is too low to deter airlines from bumping passengers?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that passengers should be treated as economic units devoid of humanity in the context of airline bumping policies?

If airline passengers are treated as economic units devoid of humanity when it comes to bumping, why should they not be treated as human beings deserving of fair and reasonable compensation for the inconvenience and losses incurred?

If DOT's objective is to eliminate all bumping, then why should the financial penalty to the airline be limited to the 100% of the total ticket price for expected arrival within 2 hours later, rather than being stronger to prevent bumping altogether?

citizen-s_176.input:
citizen-s: "I strongly support cash compensation for bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets,
But to assure adequate compensation and prevent airlines gaming such a requirement,
compensation should be at the average (cash) ticket price for that service class on that flight.
DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket would encourage airlines to bump those with zeroprice tickets first,
since that cost would be lowest.
As long as they continue to offer tickets for miles, airlines should not be encouraged to treat passengers using those tickets as secondclass when it comes to bumping.
The growing scarcity of actual seats for miles
something that cries out for regulatory intervention
is bad enough."

cqs.cq: Would the DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket actually cause airlines to prioritize bumping passengers with zero-price tickets over those with standard tickets?
Do you have a scientific study that supports the notion that passengers with zero-price tickets are more likely to be bumped than those with higher-priced tickets?

If passengers with zero-price tickets are prioritized for bumping due to the lowest fare, would this not create an incentive for airlines to prioritize those with zero-price tickets over those who have paid the average cash price?

If we prioritize fairness in bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets, wouldn't DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket price actually incentivize airlines to unfairly target those passengers?

darawayne_121.input:
darawayne: "The price of fuel doesn't change while I am trying to book a flight.
Maybe airlines should only be allowed to change prices once a week, or once a day, always at midnight, or something like that.
It is extremely frustrating to try to buy a ticket and have availability and/or price change while you are pushing the "Buy" button."

cqs.cq: Would allowing airlines to change prices only once a week, or once a day, at a specific time, significantly reduce the frustration experienced by travelers when trying to book a flight?
Do you have any data or studies that suggest that airlines' dynamic pricing strategies are more beneficial to consumers than causing frustration and anxiety?
If airlines can adjust fuel prices to increase their revenue, why can't they also adjust ticket prices to maximize their profits in real-time, just like they do with fuel?
If airlines can't control their prices, shouldn't they be held accountable for the frustration and stress they cause when customers try to book flights?

darawayne_182.input:
darawayne: "This is the same as bumping and should be compensated (punishment to the airlines) as such.
It is not just the five hours, though that is bad enough; it is all the other inconveniences, arriving late at night, having to cancel engagements, having to call a cab for a long ride vs bus transportation, and a myriad other inconveniences for which the airlines in their hubris currently accepts no responsibility."
 < this message is answering to > 
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: If passengers are not compensated for the inconvenience of changed flight schedules, do they not have a cause to claim that airlines should be held accountable for their punitive actions?

Do you have any scientific evidence or industry data that supports the notion that airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking, or is this a subjective opinion based on personal experiences like yours?

If the airline can charge passengers $150 to change their itinerary for personal reasons, should the airline not also compensate passengers for the inconveniences caused by the airline's schedule changes?

If the airlines can charge passengers hundreds of dollars to change their itineraries for personal reasons, why can't they also be required to compensate passengers for the inconveniences caused by their own schedule changes?

JDwyer_17.input:
JDwyer: "Size of aircraft should be irrelevant.
I was trapped on a very small (approx 21 passengers) aircraft, in the hot summer sun, for hours, with no ventilation.
Outrageous!
Being cooked in a small tin can is no better than being cooked in a big one!"

cqs.cq: Does the cause of a small aircraft size, in this case the risk of heatstroke, affect the decision to prioritize passenger safety in aircraft design?
Does your experience in a small aircraft justify a claim that the size of aircraft is irrelevant to passenger comfort?
If the size of an aircraft can be irrelevant in terms of its safety, would the size of a prison cell also be irrelevant in terms of its impact on an inmate's experience?
Does the logic that the size of an aircraft has no bearing on its safety also imply that the size of a prison cell has no bearing on the severity of a sentence?

JJMurray_140.input:
JJMurray: "Make the compensation exactly what it is intended to be...
the cost (or double the cost) of the ticket, no cap since there is no cap on how much you may pay for that ticket.
Frequent flyer miles should simply be refunded
or a double amount refunded
in the same way as a cash ticket is handled.
Keep this simple and it will work much better.
On smaller flights, use the same rules.
Again, keep it simple.
Best way to give passengers information is to post it online, on a legible sign in the gate area, and in print large enough to read on tickets.
If people won't take the time to read at least one of those sources then they only have themselves to blame for not knowing about this."

cqs.cq: If passengers aren't informed about the refund rules for frequent flyer miles, can they still be held accountable for not knowing how the system works?
Does the proposed policy of refunding double the cost of a ticket in the same manner as a cash ticket, without any cap, have any basis in existing airline industry standards or regulations?

If passengers are expected to be responsible for reading and understanding airline policies, why should airlines not be held responsible for clearly communicating those policies in a way that is easily accessible to all passengers?
If passengers are expected to be informed about the refund policy, why should it be displayed in ways that may be ignored by people who can't or won't take the time to read?

JJMurray_143.input:
JJMurray: "No, no, no!
If you have an allergy to peanuts and you know you have it then take your own precautions.
If I decide to bring a bag of peanuts onboard an airplane and am then told I'm in a "peanut free zone" or something like that, then my rights have been trampled as have the rights of everyone in that zone.
Request peanut free services from the airlines for yourself,
but do not force those restrictions on the rest of the flying public.
I have no problem with the airline offering peanut free foods, etc.
but it should be an option that people can select
not a requirement for everyone else to abide by.
What's next?
Can I have all perfume banned from an airplane or have people wearing them banned?
How about deodorants, hair sprays, any product with latex in it?
It is not a "right" if you have to impose that behavior on others for yourself."

cqs.cq: If people with allergies have the right to demand peanut-free services, do they also have the right to demand perfume-free or latex-free services?
Do you believe that if you have a personal allergy, it should be your responsibility to take precautions, rather than requiring the entire flight to accommodate your needs?
If people with allergies can opt for peanut-free zones, why should those with sensitivities to other substances not be able to request similar accommodations?
If JJMurray can request peanut-free services for himself, why should he not also be able to request perfume-free or latex-free services for himself?

JJMurray_166.input:
JJMurray: "I have no problem with airlines developing their own policies vice a mandated government requirement
but whatever those policies are they need to be easy to find, easy to read and understandable by your "average" person before someone books and pays for a flight.
If you want to regulate this then insist that all policies related to overbooking, rebooking, rerouting, basically any changes to the originally contracted flight must be made available in a format that is easily accessible and understandable to the general public."

cqs.cq: Would airlines be able to effectively communicate and implement these policies to the average person if they are not held accountable for their clarity and accessibility?

Do you think it's reasonable to expect airline policies to be written in a manner that's more accessible than the average contract, given that contracts are often written by lawyers and can be notoriously difficult to understand?

If airline policies are supposed to be easy to find, read, and understand for the average person, wouldn't government regulations and laws regarding consumer rights and protections also need to be made accessible and understandable to the general public?
If airlines have to clearly disclose their policies, why should consumers still be forced to pay for flights without knowing the actual terms and conditions that might change their travel experience?

JJMurray_180.input:
JJMurray: "a classic example above.
Don't just ban peanuts,
ban everything that might contain something which may have encountered a peanut or peanut product in it's life.
Once you start a ban on one product, you better be prepared for more and more demands to ban a lot of other items."
 < this message is answering to > 
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack.
Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' failure to thoroughly clean their fleets for peanut residue might cause severe reactions in passengers with peanut allergies, potentially affecting their health and well-being?
Do you have a scientific study that confirms the likelihood of peanut exposure in aircraft poses a significant risk to passengers with severe allergies, warranting the removal of peanuts from planes?

If airlines can effectively eliminate the presence of peanuts from aircraft through repeated standard cleanings, would that not be sufficient to mitigate the risk of peanut exposure for passengers with severe allergies?

If we prioritize the safety of passengers with peanut allergies, should we not demand a more comprehensive solution than merely removing peanuts and relying on airlines' good faith efforts at cleaning?

JL_15.input:
JL: "The consumer credit industry is very highly regulated
The regulations have been over-hauled three times in the last decade"

cqs.cq: Do the repeated overhauls of regulations in the consumer credit industry suggest that the current regulations are ineffective or that the industry is subject to significant cause-and-effect issues?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the consumer credit industry being highly regulated is a result of its inherent nature rather than other factors?
If the consumer credit industry is highly regulated, would the lack of regulation in the fintech industry not pose similar risks and consequences for consumers?
If the consumer credit industry is so heavily regulated, why does it still seem to have issues with predatory lending practices?

JL_3.input:
JL: "Oh, I don’t think that’s true at all
You don’t pay an interest rate
The interest rate varies by the amount of the charge for the credit but also the time over which you repay it
So if you borrow some money from me, and you pay it back very quickly, the interest rate will be much higher than if you pay it back over a long period
But the amount it costs you is exactly the same"

cqs.cq: Does the varying interest rate cause the amount you pay to be the same?
Does your explanation of how interest rates work in credit borrowing align with the actual mechanics of interest rate calculation as described by financial experts?

If a credit borrower pays back a loan in a short period, why would the interest rate be higher than if they pay it back over a long period, yet a person's natural hair texture is seen as less professional than chemically altered hair?
If the interest rate varies based on the time of repayment, why does the borrower's responsibility not also vary based on the lender's financial needs?

JL_5.input:
JL: "Because they’re very short-term loans
if you borrowed £200 from me, and in 30 days time you pay back £250, the interest rate on that is 1,413.01%
It sounds horrendous
...
But if you pay me back the same amount of money in six months time the interest rate is only 57.3%.
And if you take a year to pay it back it goes down"

cqs.cq: What if the significant difference in interest rates is a cause that affects the financial decisions of borrowers who need short-term loans?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that interest rates decrease as the loan repayment period increases?
Does the lender's interest rate decrease significantly over time, in the same manner that the perceived importance of certain loans decreases over time?
Is it morally justifiable to charge such a high interest rate on short-term loans that is nearly 14 times the rate of the same loan if paid back in a year?

JW_41.input:
JW: "It’s only since the state intervened that people have been uninterested in which bank they put their money in
In the old days of early capitalism, bankers were famously prudent people. And they went to great lengths to advertise how prudent they were.
This stopped not because of the big bang, which liberalised banking, which is what everybody thinks.
It stopped because of government guarantees to depositors."

cqs.cq: Would the reduction in prudence among bankers be a cause of the decrease in consumer interest in choosing which bank to use?
Do you have any evidence from historical records or economic literature that suggests the shift in banking practices you described was solely due to government guarantees rather than other factors?
If prudent bankers were indeed famous for their prudence before government guarantees, would the absence of such guarantees make their prudence irrelevant?
If prudent bankers were once so diligent in advertising their prudence, doesn't the state's guarantee now make them less responsible in their financial decisions?

Javier_84.input:
Javier: "I have no problem requiring the airlines to give notification of any "known" delays within 30 minutes of when they become aware of it.
BUT, being a frequent traveler, I see all sorts of problems which are unavoidable and for which the airlines will be blamed by giving such notice with the intend that some flyers may be able to delay thier trip to the airport or even the departure gate.
I know that many times the airlines can't also know exactly when a weather hold or a maintenance issue will be rectified and that the flight is then ready to go.
Many time it can be surprisingly faster than expected.
The problem is that some flyers may then  wait before going to the airport,
but then find that the problem was rectified sooner than expected and the flight departed.
Of course the flyer and the flyers rights organization will then crucify the airlines for such poor planning.
Flyers need to grow up and quit pouting and blaming everthing on the airlines.
They can't have it both ways."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' inability to provide timely notifications of delays causes passengers to make uninformed decisions about their travel plans?
Do you think it's fair to expect airlines to provide a 30-minute notification for delays when they may not have control over unpredictable factors like weather or maintenance issues?
If airlines are held accountable for delays they can't control, would passengers be held accountable for their lack of flexibility in the face of unforeseen circumstances?

If airlines are expected to provide timely notifications of delays, does that not create unrealistic expectations and potential false hope for flyers, rather than simply advising them to be flexible and adaptable?

JetJock_156_1.input:
JetJock: "Yes, most airlines pay flight crew members scheduled flight time or actual time away from the gate whichever is more.
Eg. if a flight is scheduled for 2 hours "block to block" (from/to the gate) but it takes 3 to fly it, the crew gets 3.
If the flight leaves that gate and returns 2.5 hours later, most airlines only pay that crew either the 2.0 scheduled (if it cancels) or much less.
For most crewmembers, the notion that 1 hour at the gate, 2.5 hours of sitting on that taxiway and only get paid for 2 is not very palatable.
Whereas sitting for 2.5 hours then fly 2 totals 4.5.
It is mostly the pay structure of pilots/flight attendants that poorly designed.
Most people would balk at the notion of working 4.5 hours and getting paid for 2.
The ground delay limitation, has, well, it's limitations."

cqs.cq: If airlines pay crew members for the actual time away from the gate, then does this cause a significant increase in flight crew job satisfaction?
Do you have any industry data or expert opinion that supports the claim that the current pay structure of pilots/flight attendants is "poorly designed" in the context of ground delay compensation?
Would the same logic apply to pilots/flight attendants if they were paid only for the time spent on the ground, rather than the total time from block to block?
If airlines pay flight crew members for scheduled flight time or actual time away from the gate, then why do they not also compensate them for the time spent waiting on the taxiway?

JetJock_156_2.input:
JetJock: "If we were in preregulation days where an airline was making money with only 60% of the seats filled, flights canceling due to the 3 hour limit would not be much of a problem.
What is a problem is flights that are now being canceled because of the new rule
and virtually no seats available on subsequent flights to accommodate those passengers.
If the ground delays are due to ATC, weather, VIP movement (president in the area) then passengers will not be, as a rule, given cancellation perks since they are beyond the control of the company.
If the air conditioning, and restrooms are functioning properly and there are plenty of beverages and snacks on board then that maximum number of hours should be flexible.
I would be curious to hear from people that had their flight cancel due to the 3 hour limit and how the airlines handled them after that.
My guess this rule will cause greater damage to air travel then the occasional extended ground hold on an airplane with poor air conditioning or nonfunctioning lavatories.
if the airplane is comfortable and exceeding the 3 hour limit would cancel the flight with no hotel or meal compensation, would exceeding the 3 hours be ok and if so what would be a reasonable number above 3 be?"

cqs.cq: Would the airline's decision to cancel flights due to the 3-hour limit cause a decrease in passenger satisfaction, potentially leading to a loss of customer loyalty and ultimately affecting the airline's long-term financial performance?

Do you believe that the 3-hour limit rule would be more damaging to air travel if the airline's primary concerns are passenger comfort and amenities rather than flight cancellations due to uncontrollable factors?

If airlines are willing to cancel flights due to a 3-hour ground delay and offer compensation, should they not also provide similar compensation for flights canceled due to the new 3-hour rule, which seems to be a similar situation?
If airlines can cancel flights due to the 3 hour limit and not provide compensation, can they also cancel flights due to other issues and not provide compensation?

KHenrickson_172.input:
KHenrickson: "The notification isn't so much a problem at most airports.
The electronic boards are usually updated minute by minute.
The problem is that the airlines will say "Flight 100, delayed till 7:00pm." then "Flight 100, delayed till 7:05pm".  And so on and so forth.
They're notifying everyone...with completely useless information.
Forcing them to do so more frequently isn't going to fix a thing.
Forcing them to come up with an accurate estimate is what is needed."

cqs.cq: What if the constant delay updates by the airlines are causing unnecessary stress and anxiety for travelers, rather than accurately estimating flight delays?
Do you believe that the minute-by-minute updates of flight delays by airlines are a more significant problem than the initial delay notification itself?

If airlines are forced to provide minute-by-minute updates on flight delays, would it not be more beneficial for them to invest in developing accurate estimation systems rather than merely notifying passengers with repetitive, yet irrelevant information?
If the airlines' minute-by-minute updates of flight delays provide no useful information, then what is the point of requiring them to update the information so frequently?

MP_22.input:
MP: "Well, you say the banks are the lenders
there are lots of other people who are lenders too
I mean everyone who puts money into a bank, or a building society, is putting it there so that the bank can lend it on
I mean you just heard Simon Rose say
there’s been 100 billion pounds transfer from savers to borrowers
So if you're going to raise your banner for anybody who’s doing badly in this situation, I would have thought you might have raised it for savers, in the first instance"

cqs.cq: If the banks are indeed the lenders, then why does the MP not raise their banner for savers who are also lenders, but rather for borrowers who are the recipients of the loans?
Can you point to any evidence that suggests savers are not responsible for the 100 billion pounds transfer to borrowers, rather than the banks themselves?
If the banks are indeed just conduits for lenders, why should the burden of blame fall on the banks rather than the true lenders, who are the individuals who initially deposited their money?
If everyone who puts money into a bank or a building society is a lender, then shouldn't the MP also raise their banner for savers, who have also been losing money, rather than just the banks?

MP_48.input:
MP: "	I think it’s very interesting that capitalism is coming under such a lot of attack here
And I don’t say that’s inappropriate
But we haven’t yet attacked democracy
I mean one of the things that strikes me about this is that when you have incumbent governments, and they see that consumer credit boom mushrooming and mushrooming, what do they do?
They don’t want to stop it
They don’t want to stop it, because they want voters.
They want voters who feel artificially rich
because voters who feel artificially rich will probably vote for the incumbent"

cqs.cq: What if the desire of incumbent governments to maintain consumer credit and artificially rich voters causes them to prioritize economic growth over potential long-term consequences?

Do you believe the notion that voters who feel artificially rich are more likely to vote for the incumbent is a sufficient explanation for the lack of government intervention in consumer credit booms?
If governments are willing to manipulate consumer credit to create artificially wealthy voters, would that not imply a willingness to undermine the democratic process?
If we're criticizing capitalism for creating artificial wealth, shouldn't we also scrutinize democracy for creating artificial voters?

MR_TELEVOID__178.input:
MR: "Maybe you're just the only one who gives a shit about their hair"
 < this message is answering to > 
XxEnder: "Am I the only one who noticed that Bernie combed his hair"

cqs.cq: Does XxEnder's observation of Bernie's hair suggest that he is more invested in the subject than the others who seem indifferent?
Do you have any evidence that supports the claim that Bernie's hair being combed is the only thing that matters in this conversation?
If Bernie combed his hair, would that not make him less authentic in the same way his hair is considered less authentic?
If XxEnder's concern about Bernie's hair is genuine, why does he still focus on it rather than addressing the more pressing issue of his own hair?

MT_10.input:
MT: "we know from lots and lots of research, you know this, that people aren’t very good at understanding financial products
And they're easily seduced into acting, in the short-term, in ways which aren’t very good for them in the long-term
Doesn’t the history of the financial services industry demonstrate that this is an industry with a deep commitment to exploiting those weaknesses, in order to make a fast buck?"

cqs.cq: Does the financial services industry's history of exploiting people's financial literacy weaknesses cause its reputation for prioritizing short-term profits over long-term customer well-being?
Doesn't the history of the financial services industry demonstrate that this is an industry with a deep commitment to exploiting those weaknesses, in order to make a fast buck?
Does the financial services industry's history of exploiting consumer weaknesses not resemble a history of colonial powers exploiting indigenous populations?
Doesn’t the history of the financial services industry demonstrate that this is an industry with a deep commitment to exploiting those weaknesses, in order to make a fast buck?

MT_40.input:
MT: "I don’t think you just said the opposite of them was neutral
So if they're virtues, doesn’t that imply that the opposite of thrift and prudence is immoral?
But, hold on
Isn’t it simply the case that buying a cup of coffee is something which is substantially less demanding than working up a long-term interest rate?
Therefore isn’t it a reasonable thing for the state to intervene in those cases
because the knowledge is bounded?"

cqs.cq: Doesn't the fact that virtues like thrift and prudence being immoral would imply a causal link between the state intervening in economic decisions and the moral character of those decisions?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the state has a moral obligation to intervene in cases where financial decisions are made, but not in cases where personal choices like buying a cup of coffee are made?
If virtues like thrift and prudence are considered beneficial, doesn't that imply that their opposites, profligacy and recklessness, are also desirable?
If virtues like thrift and prudence are morally superior, then doesn't that imply that their opposites, such as extravagance and recklessness, are morally inferior?

Melanie_64.input:
Melanie: "Well the State has taken a moral position
that position was non-judgmentalism
and terrible harm it’s done
It’s created a lot of victims who now need help themselves, and who sometimes go on to create other victims through crime
 I think they do need help
but that help should be very carefully calibrated, to restore the capacity for independence and personal responsibility"

cqs.cq: Does the State's non-judgmentalism cause the creation of victims who then go on to cause further harm through crime?
Do you consider the State's non-judgmentalism approach as a form of enabling or empowering when it potentially leads to more victims?
If the State's moral position prioritizes non-judgmentalism, would that not imply that victims of its policies should be treated with the same empathy and compassion as those who perpetuate harm?
If the State's non-judgmentalism is supposed to be morally neutral, then how can it justify its actions that have caused so much harm and created victims who may go on to perpetuate further harm?

Mpogoda_184.input:
Mpogoda: "As a frequent traveler, I would welcome the rule requiring 24 hour refundability of fares + all fees.
Additionally, there should be a certain window,
say, 3 days prior to flying where you should be able to cancel your flight without penalty and receive a refund or at least the ability to change your itinerary without fee.
As I always say to all who will listen,
the airline model is one of the worst business models I know of:
treat your customers with disdain and make it as inconvenient as possible for them to use your product.
Whether it be added fees to check luggage
making it too costly to change your itinerary;
making it virtually impossible to easily use frequent flyer miles or charging an exorbitant amount to actually use them;
not getting timely notice when there are delays to flights
or, even worse, when a flight has been canceled;
and lastly, being treated like cattle at the airport and on the plane."

cqs.cq: What if the airline model prioritizes profit over customer satisfaction, would that cause customers to lose trust in the airline and ultimately affect their loyalty and business decisions?
Do you have a scientific study or industry data that supports the claim that the airline business model you've described is indeed one of the worst among all industries?
Would treating airline customers with disdain and making their experience inconvenient be considered analogous to how some companies treat their customers in other industries?

If airlines can provide a 24-hour refundability of fares and allow cancellations or itinerary changes without fees, shouldn't they also be required to provide timely notice and fair treatment to their customers during flight delays or cancellations?

MrFordization__82.input:
MrFordization: "Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat
Maybe he just knows more than you"

cqs.cq: Does the Pentagon's classification of global warming as a national security threat cause them to develop more effective military strategies to mitigate its effects?
Does Mr. Ford's classification of global warming as a national security threat align with the consensus of the scientific community or is it a personal opinion?
If the Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat, does that imply that Mr. Ford's statement is an example of a national security threat being taken seriously?
If the Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat, does that imply that the US government is more concerned about its potential impacts than the general public?

Mulder_112.input:
Mulder: "Your argument is a strawman.
Nobody is advocating funerals;
you're just trying to deflect attention away from the issue,
which is that there is no real risk to peanut allergy sufferers.
And there is no scientific evidence to support your argument.
You can't even cite the studies you claim exist,
because they don't exist.
The only mean spirited people are those like yourself, who want to trample the rights of the majority for a nonexistent risk that affects a very small number of people.
This has nothing to do with the founding of the U.S. at all."

cqs.cq: Does the lack of scientific evidence to support your argument, and the inability to cite studies that allegedly exist, undermine your claim that there is a real risk to peanut allergy sufferers?
Can you provide any scientific evidence or credible sources to support your claim that peanut allergy sufferers pose a significant risk that warrants restricting the rights of the majority?

If advocating for the rights of a small group who are affected by a nonexistent risk is considered mean-spirited, wouldn't that also describe the actions of those who refuse to acknowledge the historical injustices faced by marginalized groups in the founding of the U.S.?

If there's no scientific evidence to support the claim about the risk to peanut allergy sufferers, then why are you advocating for a law that restricts the rights of the majority based on a hypothetical concern that affects a very small number of people?

Mulder_226.input:
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."
 < this message is answering to > 
Samsmom: "I am utterly amazed at the ignorance displayed by some of those commenting here.
Allergies are not "perceived"
as Mulder suggests,
and it is ridiculous and unrealistic  to suggest that people with severe food allergies "live in a bubble".
No one who has an allergy chooses to be in this situation,
and walking onto an airplane where peanuts either are being consumed or have been consumed is like playing Russian Roulette.
We are talking about a SNACK ON AN AIRPLANE.
Can you really be complaining about your rights to eat a snack?!?
My son could DIE because you can't forgo a snack for two hours.
While we could drive everywhere we need to go for the rest of his life,
there may come a time when time constraints force us to fly.
No matter how much "responsibility we take", we cannot sufficiently protect him if people around us are eating any peanut product.
We always carry an epipen,
and feel that should be our responsibility.
But, again, that may not be enough to save his life.
Those autoinjectors can only buy us 1015 minutes,
barely enough time for a plane to request an emergency landing site.
He would be dead before we taxied to the gate.
FOR A SNACK!!
An outright ban should be in place."

cqs.cq: Does the severity of a peanut allergy outweigh the convenience of in-flight snacks, potentially causing a life-threatening situation for those with such allergies?
Do you have any scientific evidence or studies that support the claim that the risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut dust or oil on an airplane is high enough to justify an outright ban on snacks?

If the risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut dust or oil is a valid concern for a child with a severe peanut allergy, why should the risk of a snack being served on an airplane not be a valid concern for the child's safety?
If Samsmom's child can die from a peanut allergy, why should others be forced to forgo snacks on an airplane when epipens and other safety measures can provide a 15-minute window of protection?

Mulder_240.input:
Mulder: "You're the one who seems to be partisan.
Instead of thinking logically about it, you try to deflect blame for your misguided apprehension onto others by insinuating they have a compulsion.
Serving and eating peanuts is not a public health menace,
so you need to get over it.
Instead of conflating the possible with the inevitable, you should focus on the reality, which is that the possibility is extremely small.
You're more likely to die from getting hit by a car crossing the street, yet you're not advocating we ban driving.
That's being a hypocrite."
 < this message is answering to > 
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."

cqs.cq: Is it possible that the partisan advocate's compulsion to serve peanuts on airplanes is the sole cause of the public health menace they claim exists?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace?

Does the analogy of equating serving peanuts on airplanes with tobacco smoking not also imply that the public health menace in this context is not the peanuts themselves, but the irresponsible behavior of consuming them in a confined space?
If serving and eating peanuts on airplanes is indeed a public health menace, then shouldn't we also consider banning the consumption of peanuts on the ground, given the same health risks?

ND_28.input:
ND: "In some ways I agree with you
If you want the economy to run smoothly, you have to incentivise certain types of behaviour.
So, for example in South Korea, in terms of how South Korean grew, it did incentivise saving, at certain times, by certain economic policies
On the other hand, I think what people don’t realise, or only half realise, is the fact that we have actually written off massive amounts of debt
But it certainly isn’t the debts of the people who most need it in society
For productive investments. I agree with you."

cqs.cq: Does incentivising certain types of behaviour in South Korea, through economic policies, actually cause the wealth gap to widen between those who benefit from the policies and those who are burdened by the written-off debt?

Do you consider the economic policies that incentivize saving in South Korea as a successful model, despite the fact that they disproportionately benefit those who are already economically advantaged?

If South Korea's economic policies incentivized saving and productive investments, why would similar policies not also be used to incentivize social mobility and economic growth among marginalized communities in society?
If South Korea's economic policies incentivised saving, then wouldn't similar policies also incentivise spending, which might be necessary for certain individuals who are struggling financially?

NYCMuscleman18_161.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: Would the current airline weight-based pricing system cause a significant increase in the number of passengers who would be unable to afford flights, thereby affecting their access to travel?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that airlines should be allowed to discriminate against passengers based on weight without regulatory action?

If airlines are allowed to charge passengers based on weight without facing regulatory action, would this not imply that the airline industry has the authority to discriminate against passengers based on other characteristics like age, gender, or ethnicity?
If airline passengers are already being weighed, shouldn't the weight of the 250lb man next to you also be considered when determining the fee, rather than just your weight alone?

NYCMuscleman18_187.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "Agreed.
The most frustrating thing about airline travel is the lack of space.
I don't see why they care so much about letting people game the bumping system, but not at all about personal space.
I guess the big question is, what's DOT's job, exactly?
Is this about inair convenience?
Avoiding pricegouging?
Or something else?"
 < this message is answering to > 
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: Does the airline's policy of charging for extra legroom or bumping passengers to a different seat cause a health issue that affects their ability to fly safely?
Do you consider the DOT's primary responsibility in this scenario to be ensuring passenger health and safety, or is it more about regulating airline practices to protect consumers from price gouging?
Would the DOT's job in this context be analogous to a referee in a boxing match, where the referee ensures fairness and safety, rather than merely addressing convenience or price gouging?

If airlines are prioritizing passenger health by providing in-flight exercises to prevent deep vein thrombosis, why do they not prioritize passenger space and comfort to prevent the same health issues?

PeanutAllergy_232.input:
PeanutAllergy: "My son is allergic to peanuts.
The last time we flew on an airline that served peanuts (Southwest) we called ahead and requested that no peanuts be served on our flight.
The airline was extremely accommodating, but there were peanuts on the floor and between the seats from earlier flights.
For that reason, I don't see banning peanuts on specific flights or a peanutfree buffer zone as real solutions.
We now only fly airlines that don't serve peanuts.
We're okay with Snickers because the peanuts are less likely to get spilled.
However, this wouldn't be a good solution for those with an inhalation allergy.
Maybe the ban could extend to all foods when there is a specific request."

cqs.cq: Does banning peanuts on specific flights or creating a peanut-free buffer zone truly address the cause of peanut allergies, or does it merely address the symptoms?
Do you believe that airlines should be required to accommodate the needs of passengers with peanut allergies, despite the inconvenience it may cause for other passengers?

If people with peanut allergies are required to take precautions to avoid exposure to peanuts on flights, would it not be reasonable for people with other food allergies to be accommodated in a similar manner?
If airlines can accommodate peanut-free flights, why can't they also accommodate peanut-free planes?

PracticalJo_179_1.input:
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack."

cqs.cq: Would removing peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter from airplanes actually cause a significant decrease in peanut-related health issues among passengers?
Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that the risks associated with peanuts and peanut-containing items on airplanes outweigh the inconvenience of removing them?
If peanuts are hazardous due to their potential to cause severe reactions upon ingestion or contact, why should airline companies continue to provide them as an in-flight snack option?
If peanuts are a health risk, why not also remove other potential allergens like shellfish or tree nuts from planes?

PracticalJo_179_2.input:
PracticalJo: "Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: Would the requirement that airlines provide EpiPens to passengers with severe allergies cause a significant increase in the overall cost to the airline industry?
Do you have a scientific source or industry standard that confirms the efficacy of "good faith effort" as a sufficient safety measure for airline cleaning protocols?
If airlines can safely allow passengers with severe allergies to bring their own EpiPens, why can't they also be required to provide an environment free from allergens like peanuts?

If the rule is primarily aimed at ensuring passenger safety, why does it not mandate a more thorough cleaning process to eliminate potential allergens, rather than just relying on "good faith efforts" from airlines?

Qubbin_80.input:
Qubbin: "I generally support the idea,
but it should be limited only to those fees which are variable,
They should not be allowed to list fees separately that are part of a ticket fee for every ticket issued,
This process serves no purpose other than to show a lower base fee.
That is misleading and meaningless.
If they want to show these components of a ticket, so be it,
but not to suggest a price which could never be exercised."

cqs.cq: Does the practice of listing separate fees for components of a ticket fee actually cause consumers to believe they have more control over their ticket purchases?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that separating ticket fees into components is misleading and meaningless?
If a ticket fee can be broken down into variable components, would this not imply that those components could indeed be exercised separately?
If the general support for the idea is based on transparency, why does the proposed process not allow for a clear breakdown of the variable fees, instead of potentially misleading consumers?

SWong_118_1.input:
SWong: "My son is severely allergic to peanuts and has allergic reactions as a result of being around people eating peanuts due to the peanut dust in the air.
We had to travel internationally and were able to work with the airline to book peanut free roundtrip flights after submitting a letter from my son's allergist.
The airline did everything they could including serving snacks without peanuts, putting allergy alert stickers on our seats, and making an announcement asking passengers to refrain from eating their peanut snacks.
My son was fine going to our destination but had an allergic reaction within minutes of being seated for our return trip.
Since he didn't eat any peanuts, we gave him some benadryl, moved him to a different row, and wiped down his new seat.
We were fortunate that his reaction was not severe enough to require an epipen injection and a trip to the hospital in another country."

cqs.cq: What if the airline's efforts to accommodate your son's peanut allergy were so inadequate that they inadvertently caused his allergic reaction to worsen on the return trip?

Do you have any scientific evidence that suggests the airline's efforts to accommodate your son's peanut allergy, such as serving peanut-free snacks, placing allergy alert stickers on seats, and making an announcement asking passengers to refrain from eating peanuts, were effective in preventing his allergic reaction on the return trip?

If airlines can accommodate passengers with peanut allergies to the extent of removing peanuts from the snack menu and designating allergy alert stickers on seats, why can't they also provide accommodations for passengers with other allergies or health conditions, such as anxiety or autism?

If the airline went to such great lengths to accommodate my son's peanut allergy on the way to our destination, why didn't they take similar precautions on the return trip to prevent his allergic reaction?

SWong_118_2.input:
SWong: "We suspect that he was reacting to peanut residue in the area of his seat from the previous flight.
We may not be so lucky next time because we have been told that the next reaction is even stronger than the last.
Even though we were on a peanutfree fight, my son still was not safe because of the peanut residue on the plane from a previous flight.
If peanuts are banned on all flights, my son would have been safe.
When an allergic reaction occurs high up in the sky over a huge ocean, and an epipen injection can only give a person an extra 20 minutes, there is not enough time to turn the plane around and take the person to the hospital.
I believe that it is reasonable to ban peanuts from airline flights if that assures the safety of a passenger that has a severe peanut allergy.
This decision could mean life or death for someone."

cqs.cq: Would banning peanuts from airline flights be a sufficient cause to prevent life-threatening allergic reactions among passengers with severe peanut allergies?

Do you have any scientific evidence or data suggesting that banning peanuts from airline flights would be a more effective measure in preventing severe peanut allergy reactions than other safety protocols, such as proper food handling and allergy notification procedures?

If peanuts are banned on flights to ensure the safety of passengers with severe peanut allergies, would it not be reasonable to also ban other potential allergens like shellfish or latex from flights to ensure the safety of passengers with those allergies?

If peanuts are banned on all flights and a severe peanut allergy could be fatal, then why wouldn't we prioritize the safety of passengers with life-threatening allergies over the convenience of allowing peanuts on flights?

Sithsaber__198.input:
Sithsaber: "Have you been to high school
It's shit"
 < this message is answering to > 
g: "high school is high school, college is college"

cqs.cq: Does having a high school education cause one to have a higher likelihood of having a nuanced understanding of the differences between high school and college?
Do you consider the quality of education in high school as comparable to college based solely on the phrase "high school is high school, college is college"?
If high school is considered a universal and equal experience for all, wouldn't attending college also be seen as a similarly universal and equal experience?
If he considers high school as high school, does that imply he views college as inherently different?

SofieM_128.input:
SofieM: "Keep in mind that you wouldn't be able to get out of the plane if it were in the air, either.
I think deplaning is a bit extreme,
because it could throw an already imbalanced flight schedule out of whack, and might delay flights even further or lead to cancellation.
I sat on a tarmac in London for five hours earlier this year, but I'd rather wait it out than hop off the plane and miss an opportunity to take off.
However, I see no problem with regular passenger updates on the progress of the delay."

cqs.cq: What if the practice of deplaning causes flight delays to become even more unpredictable and potentially lead to cancellations?
Do you have any evidence to support the claim that deplaning is always a more extreme measure than waiting for a delayed flight?
If passengers are allowed to deplane when a flight is delayed, would airlines also allow passengers to deplane when a flight is grounded due to mechanical issues, such as engine problems?
If deplaning is considered too extreme, shouldn't airlines also be held accountable for providing clear and timely updates on flight delays to avoid passenger frustration?

SofieM_73.input:
SofieM: "the DOT got the idea of flight notifications from the airlines themselves,
so I wouldn't be so quick to discount the incentive that customer satisfaction plays to airlines.
Here is an excerpt from the proposed rule:
"Carriers recognize the importance of timely and accurate flight information, as evidenced by the fact that many of the largest U.S. carriers promise through their customer service plans to provide passengers all known information about delays and cancellations as soon as they become aware of the issue" (48).
Any business which intends to survive has to satisfy its customers, otherwise the customers will simply stop buying their product, and the business will go bankrupt. Airlines themselves already thought up flight status notifications because there was customer demand for them.
I find it interesting that you claim neither passengers nor profits to be benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs.
Now, air fare is affordable (prices of air fares have decreased 25% since 1991) and more available to citizens than ever before.
Airlines like Southwest are benefiting exactly because they are offering low fares, serving their customer needs, which would seem to disprove your statement that both profits and passengers suffer in the status quo."

cqs.cq: Does the fact that airlines' customer service plans prioritize providing timely and accurate flight information not suggest that airlines are prioritizing customer satisfaction and, consequently, passenger convenience over profits?

Can you provide a scientific source or data that supports your claim that airlines' prioritization of customer satisfaction and profit simultaneously suffer in the current state of air transit affairs?

If airlines are able to profit from meeting customer demands, wouldn't the DOT's adoption of flight notifications also indicate that customer satisfaction plays a significant role in the airline industry?

If airlines are indeed benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs by offering low fares and satisfying customer needs, then why does the proposed rule aim to shift the responsibility of providing flight information from airlines to the DOT?

SofieM_8.input:
SofieM: "In general, I think that blanket policies on this topic would be a bad idea,
because people have varying capacities to handle travel.
For example, the first time I ever flew without a parent (13 years ago), I was 7 years old, and I went with my older brother who was 10.
We flew from Chicago to Colorado with no incident.
However, that doesn't mean that every 7 or 10 year old can handle itmany can't, and shouldn't try.
It's something that the parents themselves should decide,
because they know their children better than the airlines do.
Also, be careful when talking about "minors" flying alone on airplanes.
I didn't turn 18 until I was already a sophomore in college
Different airlines will treat this issue differently.
Applying a blanket policy will take away the options that come in an open marketplace of ideas.
If I only had one option, because every airline was required to treat "minors" in the same manner, my travel choices would have been limited, not expanded."

cqs.cq: Would a blanket policy on allowing minors to fly alone on airplanes cause a decrease in airlines' ability to cater to the unique needs of their customers?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that parents are better equipped to make decisions about their children's travel capabilities than airlines?
Would applying a blanket policy on minors flying alone on airplanes not be analogous to a one-size-fits-all approach in education, healthcare, or other areas where individual needs vary?

If SofieM believes parents should decide whether their children can fly alone, then does she also believe that parents should have more control over their children's education or healthcare decisions?

TRUMP_101.input:
TRUMP: "It 's not negotiable , no
Let her release the e-mails
Why did she delete 33,000"

cqs.cq: What if the deletion of the emails by Hillary Clinton caused the public to lose critical information about her actions as a public figure?
Do you have any credible sources to support the claim that the president's personal emails are "not negotiable" in the context of an ongoing investigation?
If the president's personal emails are deemed non-negotiable, does that not imply that the contents of those emails are also non-negotiable?
If Trump considers certain information non-negotiable, does that imply he believes some actions, like deleting 33,000 emails, are unacceptable?

dberger_74_1.input:
dberger: "There must be a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes.
It is a closed space.
I am allergic to peanuts and almonds
and I am impacted every time I fly.
A nut free zone does not work
since the dust from nuts gets in the closed air system of the plane.
For the time that people are on planes there should be consideration of others who have no control as to the reactions they have to nuts.
For almost all other foods the allergy only occurs if the food is ingested
so you can easily avoid the allergic reaction but not eating the food.
This is not true for many of us with nut allergies
we react if other people are eating the food
since it is an airborne allergy.
I do fly but I have to take multiple Benadryl pills every 4 hours to keep from reacting to the airborne dust of the nuts.
This works for now
but I always wonder when it will no longer be enough.
An epipen is not the answer
as it lasts only look enough for the plane to land
which is not a practical solution when you are flying on a long flight over water
and would certainly be a much greater inconvenience to the other passengers than a ban on nut products on planes if the plane was able to land.
The rules airlines have are ridiculous
Southwest is not nut free
they will not serve nuts
but if you fly a late flight the peanuts are all over the floor and seats.
Some other airlines have the rows around you 'nut free'
but advise you they can do nothing if the person seated next to you brings nuts on and wants to eat them."

cqs.cq: Do the current airline policies regarding nut-free zones on planes effectively prevent the airborne allergy reactions of passengers like you, who are affected by the mere presence of nut dust in the closed air system?

Do you have any scientific evidence or expert opinion that supports the claim that the presence of tree nuts and peanuts on planes poses a significant risk to the health of individuals with nut allergies, to the extent that a complete ban is necessary?

If airline companies can take steps to accommodate the needs of passengers with food allergies, why can't they also take similar precautions to protect passengers with airborne allergies to tree nuts and peanuts?
If people with nut allergies can be protected by taking medication and epipens, why can't the same airlines take measures to ensure a nut-free environment on planes?

dberger_74_2.input:
dberger: "Other airlines with advance notice will not serve nuts
but all airlines allow passengers to bring on foods including nuts
and will not stop the person from eating them if they wish to.
So you can have a 'nut free' flight and the person sitting next to you can take out their package of peanuts and eat away
and the airlines will do nothing to help you.
Again all nuts should be banned from airplanes unless it is your own private plane  then go ahead and eat what you want."

cqs.cq: Would allowing passengers to bring and consume nuts on flights cause a higher risk of in-flight nut-related incidents?

Do you believe that the airline's decision to allow passengers to bring on and eat nuts, while not enforcing a nut-free flight, is a reasonable approach to managing food allergies and dietary restrictions?

If airline passengers can freely consume their own food, including nuts, why should airlines be allowed to restrict or remove nuts from the flight when it's the airline's decision, not the passengers'?
If airlines allow passengers to bring on and eat nuts without restriction, why should they have a special "nut free" option when they can't or won't stop the person next to you from eating them?

dlpoole_223_1.input:
dlpoole: "Bumping compensation should apply to all carriers
because of the increasing use of regional carriers to serve smaller markets
and their no lesser disruptiveness and potential expense to the traveler.
Passengers may lack check cashing privileges away from their home airport, yet face unplanned and likely elevated expenses after being "bumped."
They should have a mandatory option of cash payment.
An credit card credit, if immediate, would be more secure and as useful to more passengers than either a check or cash.
The proposed compensation limits are too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking
and may be arbitrarily unfair to certain travelers.
The Wall Street Journal recently reproposed a 1977 proposal by the late economist Julian Simon of an auction that would offer bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat.
The arguments are rather compelling.
See the WSJ, June 8, 2010, "Auctions for Overbooking"  or"

cqs.cq: What if the current compensation limits are too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking, then why would they not be increased to a level that would make it more financially beneficial for passengers to give up their seats?

Do you have any scientific evidence or real-world examples that support the notion that bumped passengers would be more likely to use the proposed credit card credit option over a check or cash, rather than an auction system like the one proposed by Julian Simon?
If airlines can auction off bumped passengers' seats, why can't they also auction off the bumped passengers' compensation to ensure a more efficient and fair distribution of funds?
If airlines can profit from overbooking by offering auctions to bumped passengers, then why can't they simply provide a mandatory cash payment option to avoid such auctions?

dlpoole_223_2.input:
dlpoole: "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703303904575293011757655060.html
The airlines will overbook so as to optimize their financial results under any given set of caps,
so some passengers will still be involuntarily denied boarding on overbooked flights.
An auction will more accurately price the delay
and the sellers (the delayed passenger(s)) will be left with no complaint that it was involuntary.
An auction would also force the carriers to face the cost of overbooking in customer dissatisfaction and better inform their flight scheduling decisions.
I recall hearing seats being auctioned by progressive increases in the promised compensation by gate agents,
but that was long, long ago and under far greater seat availability and lower probabilities of cascading delays and subsequent denials of boarding for those who took the compensation.
Those procedures were surely regulated by DOT,
(perhaps when the industry was more heavily regulated,)
so perhaps those earlier rules should be revisited."

cqs.cq: What if the financial benefits of overbooking flights are causing carriers to prioritize profits over passenger comfort and satisfaction?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that involuntary denial of boarding due to overbooking in the airline industry would lead to more accurate pricing and better-informed flight scheduling decisions?
If airlines auction off the right to board flights to optimize financial results, why should passengers involuntarily denied boarding not be compensated in a similar manner?
If the airlines' practice of overbooking results in involuntary denials, shouldn't they be held accountable for the financial cost of those denials, rather than just compensating passengers?

drgreg_181_1.input:
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
